properties.Name:
Buckeye Partners East Chicago Terminal

400 E Columbus Drive, East Chicago, IN 46312
properties.EPA: Buckeye is a major oil logistics firm with global port operations in addition to tank farms and pipes. Their Chicago hub connects Alberta and North Dakota crude-by-rail flows to a pipeline system supplying refineries across the entire Northeast US, as you can see in the map. Look just south of Highway 94 to see the railcar loader alongside the Hammond terminal, which is their bid to participate in the crude-by-rail boom.

properties.Name:
Buckeye Partners Hammond Terminal

2400 Michigan Street, Hammond, IN 46320
properties.EPA: The new railcar loader can be seen in place with the spyglass. Here's the technical description: "A 24-spot railcar loading rack, constructed in 2011, and approved in 2013 for modification, designed to load/offload petroleum product in up to six (6) railcars at a time through an available twelve (12) loading arms. The railcars are 30,000 gallons per car with a total rack capacity of 180,000 gallons per hour. The loading racks emissions [that's the volatile stuff causing explosions] will be controlled by two (2) vapor combustion units." (source).
properties.website: The aim of this facility is not to receive crude (which doesn't make sense in an area bursting with pipelines) but rather, to originate crude-by-rail shipments to refineries looking for the discount prices of Bakken and Tar Sands oil. As the corporation explained in a 2013 presentation to investors: "Western Canadian and Bakken crude oil expected to be transported via pipeline into Chicago Complex for ultimate delivery to unit-train facilities on the East, Gulf, and West Coasts." (source)
